id: assets received from investors in exchange for an ownership interest
name: assets received from investors in exchange for an ownership interest

id: revenue received during a period of time
name: revenue received during a period of time

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) Annotation Vocabulary rather than the OMG's Specification Metadata vocabulary.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) Annotation Vocabulary rather than the OMG's Specification Metadata vocabulary.

id: This ontology defines equity-related concepts for use in defining other FIBO ontology elements. These are based on basic accounting principles as they relate to equity, debt, assets and liabilities of a firm. Equity forms the basis for ownership of certain forms of corporate body.
name: This ontology defines equity-related concepts for use in defining other FIBO ontology elements. These are based on basic accounting principles as they relate to equity, debt, assets and liabilities of a firm. Equity forms the basis for ownership of certain forms of corporate body.

id: If the corporation takes a loss, then that loss is retained and called variously retained losses, accumulated losses or accumulated deficit. Retained earnings and losses are cumulative from year to year with losses offsetting earnings.
name: If the corporation takes a loss, then that loss is retained and called variously retained losses, accumulated losses or accumulated deficit. Retained earnings and losses are cumulative from year to year with losses offsetting earnings.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add physical asset and eliminate ambiguity in some definitions.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add physical asset and eliminate ambiguity in some definitions.

id: net profits kept to accumulate in a business after dividends are paid
name: net profits kept to accumulate in a business after dividends are paid

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate deprecated elements.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate deprecated elements.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified per the FIBO 2.0 RFC to rework definitions in support of revised Business Entities, Equities and related ontologies.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified per the FIBO 2.0 RFC to rework definitions in support of revised Business Entities, Equities and related ontologies.

id: capital contributed in excess of the par value (stated value) of the ownership interest issued
name: capital contributed in excess of the par value (stated value) of the ownership interest issued

id: Financial assets are typically more liquid than other tangible assets, such as commodities or real estate. Financial assets may not cover all assets that might be included on a balance sheet, and do not include tangible, physical assets or intangible assets such as intellectual property.
name: Financial assets are typically more liquid than other tangible assets, such as commodities or real estate. Financial assets may not cover all assets that might be included on a balance sheet, and do not include tangible, physical assets or intangible assets such as intellectual property.

id: equity that is manifested in the form of shares in an entity, fund or structured product
name: equity that is manifested in the form of shares in an entity, fund or structured product

id: EBITDA is often used as a proxy for cash flow, as it shows how much cash a company can generate from its core operations. However, EBITDA has some limitations, such as ignoring the cost of maintaining and replacing capital assets, and being susceptible to manipulation by excluding certain expenses.
name: EBITDA is often used as a proxy for cash flow, as it shows how much cash a company can generate from its core operations. However, EBITDA has some limitations, such as ignoring the cost of maintaining and replacing capital assets, and being susceptible to manipulation by excluding certain expenses.

id: Barron's Dictionary of Banking Terms, Sixth Edition, 2012.
name: Barron's Dictionary of Banking Terms, Sixth Edition, 2012.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to fix spelling errors and deprecate the property represents an interest in, which is not used elsewhere and is confusing.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to fix spelling errors and deprecate the property represents an interest in, which is not used elsewhere and is confusing.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate the deprecated 'represents an interest in' property.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to eliminate the deprecated 'represents an interest in' property.

id: By stripping out the non-cash depreciation and amortization expense as well as taxes and debt costs dependent on the capital structure, EBITDA attempts to represent cash profit generated by the company's operations. EBITDA is not a metric recognized under Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). Some public companies report EBITDA in their quarterly results along with adjusted EBITDA figures typically excluding additional costs, such as stock-based compensation.
name: By stripping out the non-cash depreciation and amortization expense as well as taxes and debt costs dependent on the capital structure, EBITDA attempts to represent cash profit generated by the company's operations. EBITDA is not a metric recognized under Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP). Some public companies report EBITDA in their quarterly results along with adjusted EBITDA figures typically excluding additional costs, such as stock-based compensation.

id: Income includes cash or cash equivalent(s) received during some period of time in exchange for labor or services, from the sale of goods or property, or as receipts from financial investments.
name: Income includes cash or cash equivalent(s) received during some period of time in exchange for labor or services, from the sale of goods or property, or as receipts from financial investments.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to correct the definition of EBITDA and to replace content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380).
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to correct the definition of EBITDA and to replace content that is now available in the OMG Commons Ontology Library (Commons) v1.1 (FND-380).

id: measure of potential cash flow that excludes the effects of capital structure, taxes and non-cash expenses
name: measure of potential cash flow that excludes the effects of capital structure, taxes and non-cash expenses

id: earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization
name: earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified per the issue resolutions identified in the FIBO FND 1.1 RTF report, namely, to rename MoneyAmount to AmountOfMoney and replace it herein with MonetaryAmount, as appropriate.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified per the issue resolutions identified in the FIBO FND 1.1 RTF report, namely, to rename MoneyAmount to AmountOfMoney and replace it herein with MonetaryAmount, as appropriate.

id: Physical (tangible) assets are real items of value that are used to generate revenue for a company.
name: Physical (tangible) assets are real items of value that are used to generate revenue for a company.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to make income a subclass of monetary amount and eliminate the oblique restriction on monetary amount to simplify its representation.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to make income a subclass of monetary amount and eliminate the oblique restriction on monetary amount to simplify its representation.

id: Owner's equity is represented by capital investments and accumulated earnings less any dividends or other financial obligations. It is typically used to talk about equity in a business, but may also refer to the net assets of a pool or special purpose vehicle.
name: Owner's equity is represented by capital investments and accumulated earnings less any dividends or other financial obligations. It is typically used to talk about equity in a business, but may also refer to the net assets of a pool or special purpose vehicle.

id: non-physical, tangible asset whose value is derived from a contractual claim, such as bank deposits, bonds, stocks, rights, certificates, and bank balances
name: non-physical, tangible asset whose value is derived from a contractual claim, such as bank deposits, bonds, stocks, rights, certificates, and bank balances

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to augment the definition of asset, and add income.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to augment the definition of asset, and add income.

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add a definition for EBITDA.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to add a definition for EBITDA.

id: owners' share in a business plus operating profit
name: owners' share in a business plus operating profit

id: tangible asset that has a material form, such as property, equipment, and inventory
name: tangible asset that has a material form, such as property, equipment, and inventory

id: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) rather than the OMG's Languages, Countries and Codes (LCC), eliminating redundancies in FIBO as appropriate.
name: AccountingEquity.rdf version of this ontology was modified to use the Commons Ontology Library (Commons) rather than the OMG's Languages, Countries and Codes (LCC), eliminating redundancies in FIBO as appropriate.
